name: Shanghai
title: Shanghai - Traveling China like your home yard
overview: Shanghai stands as China's most cosmopolitan metropolis, a dazzling showcase of the nation's rapid transformation from ancient empire to global superpower. With a population exceeding 26 million, this megacity pulses with an energy that few places on Earth can match. The Huangpu River, which flows through the heart of Shanghai, serves as both a physical and symbolic dividing line between the city's two distinct personalities: Puxi, the historic west bank where colonial-era architecture lines the famous Bund, and Pudong, the futuristic east bank dominated by the soaring towers of China's financial district, including the Shanghai Tower, the world's second-tallest building. The city's history as a treaty port following the Opium Wars left an indelible mark on its character, creating a unique cultural blend that sets Shanghai apart from other Chinese cities. The Bund, with its collection of Art Deco and Neoclassical buildings, stands as a testament to Shanghai's former status as the 'Paris of the East,' while the nearby French Concession enchants visitors with its tree-lined avenues, boutique shops, and sidewalk cafes that evoke a distinctly European atmosphere. Yet, just blocks away, traditional shikumen lane houses and bustling wet markets remind visitors that this is still very much a Chinese city, where ancient traditions persist amidst the ultramodern skyline. Shanghai's culinary scene is equally impressive, offering everything from humble street food to Michelin-starred fine dining. The city is the birthplace of xiaolongbao, the delicate soup dumplings that have conquered taste buds worldwide, and shengjianbao, their pan-fried cousins with crispy bottoms and juicy interiors. Beyond these famous dishes, Shanghai's food culture reflects its international heritage, with restaurants serving authentic cuisine from every corner of China and beyond. Whether you're exploring the tranquil classical gardens of Yu Yuan, shopping for luxury brands on Nanjing Road, or simply watching the neon lights reflect off the Huangpu River at night, Shanghai offers an intoxicating blend of history, culture, and modernity that leaves an unforgettable impression on every visitor.

gettingThere: By Air: Shanghai Pudong International Airport (PVG) and Shanghai Hongqiao (SHA)
By Train: High-speed rail connects Shanghai to Beijing, Nanjing, Hangzhou
By Bus: Long-distance buses from nearby cities and provinces
gettingAround: Metro: World's longest metro system, efficient and affordable
Bus: Extensive bus network covering all districts
Maglev: World's fastest commercial train from Pudong Airport
Huangpu River Ferry: Scenic transportation between Puxi and Pudong
